docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama gave a feel-good campaign-style speech at a gymnasium packed with screaming high school students on Friday, sketching out the main points of his populist agenda ahead of a special election in Florida on Tuesday.

headline.main: Obama Visits Florida Ahead of Bellwether Special Election
headline.print_headline: Obama Visits Florida Ahead of Bellwether Special Election

docs.snippet: President Barack Obama gave a feel-good campaign-style speech at a gymnasium packed with screaming high school students on Friday, sketching out the main points of his populist agenda ahead of a special election in Florida on Tuesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration said on Friday Verizon Communications Inc's Terremark unit will remain under contract as host of the federal website HealthCare.gov to better ensure a smooth end to Obamacare's open enrollment period on March 31.

headline.main: U.S. Extends Terremark Contract as HealthCare.gov Host
headline.print_headline: U.S. Extends Terremark Contract as HealthCare.gov Host

docs.snippet: The Obama administration said on Friday Verizon Communications Inc's Terremark unit will remain under contract as host of the federal website HealthCare.gov to better ensure a smooth end to Obamacare's open enrollment period on March 31.

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. job growth accelerated sharply in February despite the icy weather that gripped much of the nation, easing fears of an abrupt economic slowdown and keeping the Federal Reserve on track to continue reducing its monetary stimulus.

headline.main: U.S. Job Growth Offers Upbeat Sign for Weather-Beaten Economy
headline.print_headline: U.S. Job Growth Offers Upbeat Sign for Weather-Beaten Economy

docs.snippet: U.S. job growth accelerated sharply in February despite the icy weather that gripped much of the nation, easing fears of an abrupt economic slowdown and keeping the Federal Reserve on track to continue reducing its monetary stimulus.

docs.lead_paragraph: New York is one of at least 26 states rolling out managed long-term care programs under Medicaid, but the widely praised version in Tennessee has had problems.

headline.main: Pitfalls Seen in a Turn to Privately Run Long-Term Care
headline.print_headline: Pitfalls Seen in a State’s Turn to Privately Run Long-Term Care

docs.abstract: New York is one of at least 26 states rolling out mandatory privately managed long-term care programs under Medicaid, but the widely praised version in Tennessee has had problems; system of caring for frail comes under twin pressures of cost containment and profit motive, and in many cases, care is denied after needs grew costlier.
docs.snippet: New York is one of at least 26 states rolling out managed long-term care programs under Medicaid, but the widely praised version in Tennessee has had problems.

docs.lead_paragraph: New Hampshire moved to join states like Arkansas and Iowa in the way it is choosing to use money available under the Affordable Care Act.

headline.main: New Hampshire Senate Votes to Expand Health Insurance Coverage
headline.print_headline: New Hampshire Senate Votes to Expand Health Insurance Coverage

docs.abstract: New Hampshire's Republican-dominated Senate votes to expand health care coverage to estimated 50,000 adults using Medicaid funding made available through Affordable Care Act.
docs.snippet: New Hampshire moved to join states like Arkansas and Iowa in the way it is choosing to use money available under the Affordable Care Act.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: A political maneuver allows people to renew their plans, but will they want to?
docs.abstract: Editorial asserts Obama administration's policy allowing people to renew their existing insurance policies for two more years has immediate, unfortunate effect of giving Republicans another excuse to bash Affordable Care Act; argues in truth policy change, which was enacted to help Democratic senators facing tough re-election campaigns, poses no threat to health care reform and will have no impact on majority of Americans.
docs.snippet: A political maneuver allows people to renew their plans, but will they want to?

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Some employers are offering as many as 25 health care plans to employees from a variety of insurers, including Blue Cross and UnitedHealthcare, to lower their costs for the benefit.

headline.main: Companies Test Plans to Cut Their Health Costs
headline.print_headline: Companies Test Plans to Cut Their Health Costs

docs.abstract: Companies nationwide are embracing number of new strategies to combat rising health care costs, including private insurance exchanges that can offer employees wide array of plans to choose from.
docs.snippet: Some employers are offering as many as 25 health care plans to employees from a variety of insurers, including Blue Cross and UnitedHealthcare, to lower their costs for the benefit.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Tax Reform Act of 2014 proposed by Dave Camp, a Michigan Republican, contains provisions to take away benefits from some taxpayers simply because they make too much money.

headline.main: Republican’s Tax Plan Awkwardly Aims at Rich
headline.print_headline: Republican’s Tax Plan Awkwardly Aims at Rich

docs.abstract: Floyd Norris High & Low Finances column analyzes tax reform proposal by Republican Rep Dave Camp that would take away numerous benefits and significantly raise marginal tax rate on high earners.
docs.snippet: The Tax Reform Act of 2014 proposed by Dave Camp, a Michigan Republican, contains provisions to take away benefits from some taxpayers simply because they make too much money.

docs.lead_paragraph: Before the troubled rollout of HealthCare.gov, Gary M. Cohen repeatedly told Congress that it would work well.

headline.main: Official at Helm of Federal Health Marketplace Is Resigning
headline.print_headline: Official at Helm of Federal Health Marketplace Is Resigning

docs.abstract: Gary M Cohen, official in charge of federal health insurance marketplace HealthCare.gov, says he is resigning; he repeatedly told Congress before its troubled rollout that it would work well.
docs.snippet: Before the troubled rollout of HealthCare.gov, Gary M. Cohen repeatedly told Congress that it would work well.

docs.lead_paragraph: A top U.S. healthcare official, accused by Republicans of misleading Congress about the readiness of the Obamacare rollout, will resign from his post at the end of March, officials said on Thursday.

headline.main: U.S. Official in Charge of Obamacare Exchanges Resigns
headline.print_headline: U.S. Official in Charge of Obamacare Exchanges Resigns

docs.snippet: A top U.S. healthcare official, accused by Republicans of misleading Congress about the readiness of the Obamacare rollout, will resign from his post at the end of March, officials said on Thursday.
